section.title: Summary
section.para: The JavaMacros plugin allows you to write macros in your favourite Java IDE.

The plugin uses compiled class files as macros instead of script files. This allows you to write macros in Java or any other JVM language that compiles down to class files. The main advantage is that IDE support is much better for Java then for script languages.

section.title: Usage
section.para: Supposed usage is as follows. Exact steps may differ depending on IDE choosen, or you may wish to adopt it to be more convinient to you.

itemizedlist.listitem:
create a new project in your IDE; it should:
put compiled class files to either jEdit home or ~/.jedit directory have jedit.jar from jedit distribution and javamacros.jar from plugin distribution in its classpath
create a Java package named "macros"; you can then create subpackages of it to create macros hierarchy

create a class inside "macros" package or inside one of its subpackages; the class must either implement javamacros.MacroClass or extend javamacros.SelectionTransformerMacroClass; please see javadocs for further instructions on how to write your macros
reload macros in jEdit (Macros->Rescan Macros); your Macros menu should now contain folders and items mapped to subpackages and classes in your project
